citations.narrative:
The licensee is not maintaining complete records of disposition. APHIS form 7006s (“Record of Disposition of Dogs and
Cats”) evaluated by the inspector dated from 1/5/25-3/7/25, and totaling 10 puppies, were missing information such as the
licensee’s USDA number, the delivery method, the type of disposition (sale, exchange or transfer, donation), and the
information required for the buyer listed under 2.75(a)(1)(iii): the vehicle license number and State, and the driver’s
license number and State of the person, if he or she is not licensed or registered under the Animal Welfare Act.
Additionally, no disposition records were created for approximately 3 adult Golden Retrievers retired from the facility.
Failure to provide this information may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to identify animals and to trace their
movements. Each dealer shall, make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose this
information when disposed of by that dealer. Correct by: July 30, 2025.

The facility is not following the Program of Vet Care (PVC) for fecal and heartworm sample testing. The PVC prescribes
for 10% of the adult dog population to have fecal sample testing yearly, and 5% of the total puppy litter numbers twice
yearly, as well as heartworm tests to be performed on adult dogs yearly. The facility had no record of these tests
performed since July 2023. The inspector called the office of the Attending Veterinarian to confirm if testing had been
performed and it was not. Internal parasites, which are screened for by fecal and heartworm testing, can cause illness,
stress, and discomfort to animals if present in the body. Correct by ensuring the facility follows the PVC for sampling and
treatment of parasites such as worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm, in accordance with a schedule approved by the
AV. Correct by: July 30, 2025.

A medical record was not created for adult dogs for vaccination against distemper and parvovirus. The Animal Welfare
Act requires vaccination for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs, including distemper and parvovirus (the dogs are
current on the third required vaccine, rabies). Additionally, the Program of Vet Care (PVC), also prescribes for these
vaccinations to be given to adult dogs yearly. The licensee reports he gives the vaccines in July, but there is no written
record documenting administration of said vaccines for either 2024 or 2025. Documenting medical records properly helps
USDA inspectors verify the animals at the facility are receiving appropriate veterinary care. Dealers must keep copies of
medical records for dogs and the records must include the names and dates of all vaccines given. Correct by: July 30,
2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
